speakeroldname: Right Hon. John N. Turner (Leader of the Opposition) moved:
subsubtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION-INFORMATION GUIDELINES
speechtext:
That, in the opinion of this House, the guidelines issued by the Prime Minister on November 23, 1984, with regard to the provision of information to the public, are inadequate and retrogressive and confirm the Government's mistrust of and cynicism toward Canadians.
He said: Mr. Speaker, I would like to say that I almost did not get to the House this morning because of the fog. The trip from Vancouver Quadra was a little longer than I had expected. Mind you, this fog has been descending over the capital ever since the Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney) announced his guidelines on Friday.
I rise today, Your Honour, on a very serious issue which goes right to the heart of this institution of Parliament and to the good workings of democracy itself; the right of every Canadian to complete information on the policies, plans and projects of the Government. Openness in government, Sir, is absolutely vital and fundamental to parliamentary democracy. It reinforces the confidence of Canadians in the way our system works and it promotes sound and intelligent debate among the citizenry of our country.
The Prime Minister, at his press conference on Friday, introduced guidelines for public servants as to how they must deal with members of the press, the news media and the public, indeed as to how they must deal with Hon. Members of this House. He indicated a willingness to table these guidelines in the House when I questioned him last week, but as yet I do not believe he has done so.
[ Translation]
Mr. Speaker, the Prime Minister's guidelines are important because they affect the right of all Members to be informed about Government policy in order to serve their constituents, and also the right of Canadians to have this information. However, the guidelines will not give us the open and accessible government we were promised. Far from it!

The effect of these guidelines, Mr. Speaker, will be an even tighter control on information. The Prime Minister made a solemn pledge during the campaign which I recited during Question Period a week ago and which is found in Hansard of November 20, 1984, at page 404. These are his words:
Secrecy in government... is an addiction; the more the Government can have of it, the more it wants of it.
The Prime Minister also said: "The first benefit of the first day of a new government will be the knowledge that the public business will be once more in the hands of those who trust the people and seek their goodwill and trust in reform". Those were his words. Like the economic commitments the Prime Minister made to the Canadian people, this commitment for openness in government has already been broken. First, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr. Nielsen) gagged all the Ministers. They could not talk. As I said on Leaders' day during the debate on the Throne Speech, they would be fired unless they "checked with Erik". The Secretary of State for External Affairs (Mr. Clark) then gagged his Department, gagged Canada's ambassadors and gagged our trade representatives around the world. The Secretary of State for External Affairs was particularly concerned that someone might learn something at a cocktail party.

Senior officials were hesitant to go to conferences to discuss nuclear disarmament, because they were afraid their Minister would insist on controlling whatever they said. The Minister of Finance (Mr. Wilson) even refused to give us information regarding the effects of severe cutbacks on the employment situation.
So we asked the questions in the House of Commons. We pressed the issue and forced the Prime Minister to go before the national press gallery with the guidelines. The result was that he finally came up with some rules and regulations, but instead of being the road to open government we expected they are nothing more than a forced march down the dead-end street of government secrecy. Yes, the Prime Minister lifted the gag order all right, but he replaced it with a straight-jacket on all our public servants and the complete government apparatus in Canada.
Background briefings are no longer in order. We are told in the guidelines they will only be permitted in exceptional circumstances and must have prior ministerial approval. These guidelines raise more questions than they answer. We know

November 27, 1984
Supply
this Government puts a high priority on managing the news, but what constitutes an off-the-record, background briefing? If a member of the news media, for example, asks a public servant for information on a previous policy announcement which may not be consistent with current policy, will he have to check first with the Minister before giving out that information? Does it mean that every time a policy is changed all previous policy announcements must be deep-sixed? Is every statement in support of government policy a fact and every critical statement an off-the-record briefing?
The Prime Minister's letter accompanying the guidelines says that Ministers must, and I use his words, "ensure that communication with the public is managed effectively in accordance with the priorities of the Government". The key word in the statement is "managed". What about the public interest and the public right to know? Are public servants going to be punished for talking about subjects affecting the public interest which are not necessarily priorities of the Tory Government? If a member of the public wants to know why a particular policy option was chosen over another, does the public servant in question have to check with his Minister to give that information?
What is at issue here, Mr. Speaker, is that it is one thing to allow facts to be confirmed or revealed by public servants within an umbrella of government policy, but what is important for public debate and public scrutiny is that members of this House, the media and the people of Canada know the options in front of the Government. Why was one choice made rather than another? What were the reasons and facts and policies behind that choice? What were the choices that were disregarded and refused? In other words, by limiting, in the guidelines, public servants to the mere relevation of facts within a very tight stricture and under a very strictly controlled parameter, the Prime Minister is, in effect, controlling the ability of this country to debate options, choices and to understand the reasons why the Government made a decision. That is absolutely true.

subsubtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION-INFORMATION GUIDELINES
speechtext: Shame!

subsubtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION-INFORMATION GUIDELINES
speechtext:
We have now seen the sophistication of managing the news taken to a new height in the history of our country. This is a cosmetic government, one that is operating in imperial, even presidential style, everything having to be channeled through the Prime Minister's office. I tell you, it is an awesome machine, Mr. Speaker, reinforced through the Prime Minister's office by the appointment of chiefs of staff, personally appointed in every department of government. I have called them political commissars; they are the eyes and ears of the Prime Minister in every department of state.
I thank you, Mr. Speaker, and our system that we are not, despite the Prime Minister's inclination, living under a presidential system. We are living under a parliamentary system and every day he and his Ministers will have to appear before this House. I warn him that the system he is trying to constrict and construct will not work because, while we may be short in
numbers at the moment, the House of Commons will insist that this veil of secrecy be torn aside and this shroud lifted.

subsubtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION-INFORMATION GUIDELINES
speechtext: Hear, hear!

subsubtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION-INFORMATION GUIDELINES
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in an editorial entitled "Mulroney Shuts Out Public" The Toronto Star makes the following point on the impact of these guidelines in restricting information to the public. I use The Toronto Star's words: "By reducing the opportunity for informed debate before the Government decides what it wants to do, this limits the public's ability to help shape that decision".

The Government has a very sizeable majority. Why is it so afraid that the press and the federal public service are going to gang up on it? Does the Government have so little confidence in its programs and policies that it has to resort to this kind of gross manipulation?
Why do they assume that public servants will not tell the truth? Or are they afraid that public servants will tell the truth?

subsubtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION-INFORMATION GUIDELINES
speechtext: Hear, hear!

subsubtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION-INFORMATION GUIDELINES
speechtext:
As a result of the pressure put on the Government by the Official Opposition, the Prime Minister has quietly shuffled the Deputy Prime Minister out of the sensitive role of communications overseer in the Cabinet. He has been replaced with three new Ministers; the Minister of National Revenue (Mr. Beatty), the Minister of Transport (Mr. Mazankowski) and the House Leader (Mr. Hnatyshyn). The question is, who is the spokesman? Is this the new communications troika? Will a dissenting report be published when they do not agree unanimously? How will they interlink with the political commissars to control the flow of information from the Government?
Instead of policy objectives which stand or fall on their own merit, we now have government by one-liners, government by 30-second clip, government by photo opportunity, in short, government by controlled access. If ever I saw one, this is a peek-a-boo government.

subsubtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION-INFORMATION GUIDELINES
speechtext: Hear, hear!

subsubtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION-INFORMATION GUIDELINES
speechtext: Perhaps they want to manage the news because they are afraid they cannot manage the Government. The Prime Minister says that public servants are not to defend or criticize, only to explain. How can public servants explain when they are not allowed to say anything except to spout the Party line as dictated by Ministers and political commissars? The Government's attitude to the Public Service of this country is churlish and patronizing.

subsubtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION-INFORMATION GUIDELINES
speechtext:
Hear, hear!
November 27, 1984

subsubtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION-INFORMATION GUIDELINES
speechtext:
The Prime Minister says that his Government is open. Well, the opposite is true. I suppose he feels that if he repeats it over and over everyone will eventually believe it. Mr. Speaker, we on this side of the House do not buy it. I do not believe the media accepts it, and the people of Canada certainly do not accept it.
I have said on other occasions that it is a matter of trust that governments will do what they say they will do. The Prime Minister and his colleagues said that we were to receive open, accessible and available government. That is not happening here. What we are seeing is symptomatic of an attitude, a tone and a style of government. It is manipulative and operates on imagery. It is contrived. What is the Prime Minister afraid of? Is he afraid of the inexperience of the Ministry? He could be excused for that. Is he afraid of the incompetence of the Ministry? Is he afraid of an informed electorate? Is he afraid of the revelation of his failure to live up to his promises during the election campaign?
In putting this motion to the House I say to the Prime Minister, let the people judge. Take Canadians into your confidence. Come clean with the citizenry of our country. Disband these guidelines and open up the Government to the light and corridors of power and let us have some fresh air.

subsubtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION-INFORMATION GUIDELINES
speechtext: Hear, hear!

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, at the outset I would like to thank the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Turner) for a very amusing speech. He will, of course, want to answer some questions. He has come forward with a new spirit of openness previously unknown to the Liberal Party.
With regard to manipulation, could the Leader of the Opposition explain why, before the last election, the Liberal Party increased the advertising budget of the Government of Canada by some 65 per cent over what it was in previous years? How can he justify standing before the House and making specious allegations with respect to the whole question of alleged secrecy when we are the most open government Canadians have ever had in the history of this country? How can he make this allegation when he is part of an administration which has increased manipulative advertising? How can he stand in his place and make these kinds of allegations with a serious face?

speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the hon. gentleman has tried to regain some momentum here this morning. At least advertising of public programs is increasing the information flow to government, not stemming and choking it as the hon. gentleman and his colleagues would like to do.

subsubtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION-INFORMATION GUIDELINES
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to ask the Right Hon. Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Turner) a question with respect to this new-found interest of the Liberal Party in openness in government. Is he prepared, unlike the former Prime Minister and his colleagues, to trust the courts in this

country with respect to the view of claimed exemptions under access to information legislation?
One of the glaring loopholes in the freedom of information legislation which was brought forward by his Party and unanimously condemned by all of the groups in this country who are concerned about openness in government was the Mack truck exemption clause in the Bill which meant that the Government did not trust the courts to review claimed exemptions with respect to the possibility of Cabinet documents. That flew in the face of the previous government's Bill. Although the new Government has been silent on that particular question so far, one can always hope that it might practice in government what it preached in opposition.
Is the Right Hon. Leader of the Opposition prepared to change the position of secrecy and cover-up of the previous government and trust the courts of this country in order to allow full judicial review of any claimed exemptions under access to information?

subsubtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION-INFORMATION GUIDELINES
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would think that the legislation to which he refers was a great step forward in this country in opening up the avenues of public scrutiny of legislation and also of the inner workings of government.
With respect to whether the courts should review any particular claim for an exemption, this is a classic case of parliamentary review versus judicial review. I have an open mind about it. We might well respond in a constructive way if the new Government were to move along the lines that the Hon. Member suggests.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources
subsubtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION-INFORMATION GUIDELINES
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I was interested in the Right Hon. Member's speech. He made it sound as though there have never been guidelines produced by any government before. I remember when the government in July 1981 produced the document entitled "Communications Roles and Responsibilities". It states that Ministers:
-have the responsibility for establishing, with their Deputy Ministers, the framework of priorities, strategies and objectives for communications with the public, and the communications responsibilities which are appropriate for their personal staffs and department officials?
Is it not true that this document was produced before, that there have always been certain guidelines and that in fact one of the guidelines was that public servants were not to be quoted by name in the press?

subsubtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION-INFORMATION GUIDELINES
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, of course, I have not seen those particular guidelines. I suspect that they resemble those drawn up by the previous administration under the Secretary of State for External Affairs.
In any event, what makes this particular debate so crucial is that we were led to believe by the Hon. Member's Party and his Leader, the Right Hon. Prime Minister, that whatever the history of openness in this country-we believe that we had an open government-he gave an explicit undertaking to the people of Canada in obvious reference to the past that his was going to be an open and accessible government that would tear

November 27, 1984
Supply
away what he believed were the traditions of secrecy in parliamentary life and conduct.
It is because of those undertakings which he has breached that this debate assumes the proportions it does, not only on the principle that open government is necessary for the proper workings of a free country but as a result of the fact that the Prime Minister once again is reneging on a commitment made to the Canadian people in a free and open election.

subsubtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION-INFORMATION GUIDELINES
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, first would the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Turner) go to his House Leader and get a copy of that famous Liberal document passed by Order in Council entitled "Communications Roles and Responsibilities" of July, 1981? The Leader of the Opposition is so complaining on this matter. Is it his view that the Public Service should be politicized, that members of the Public Service should be out there arguing policy issues in a partisan sense, as the former Liberal government attempted to use public servants? Or is it his view that the Public Service should act in a responsible management fashion, answering proper questions, as our guidelines indicate, and not be politicized? Does the Leader of the Opposition want to politize the Public Service? Does he want the Public Service to be part of the political debating process? Is that his attitude?

subsubtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION-INFORMATION GUIDELINES
speechtext:
No, of course not, Mr. Speaker. We do not want a politicized Public Service. We want a Public Service that is free to explain the policies of government as dictated and organized by their political masters, the Ministry of the day. That means they cannot be limited to merely factual explanations. They have to be free to explain within the mandate given to them by their Ministers the reasons for their choice and for policy decisions. They have to be able to do that.
The problem here is that by forcing each public servant to reveal his or her name at every interview, in effect a discreet silence will be imposed upon the Public Service of Canada because an individual public servant will not take the chance that what he has to say, even in a factual sense, does not meet the approval of his Minister. That is what is happening here.

subsubtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION-INFORMATION GUIDELINES
speechtext: Hear, hear!

subsubtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION-INFORMATION GUIDELINES
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the Right Hon. Leader of the Opposition is very upset about this matter.

subsubtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION-INFORMATION GUIDELINES

subsubtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION-INFORMATION GUIDELINES

Mr. Speaker, as far as the Leader of the Official Opposition (Mr. Turner) is concerned, senior officials may make all the statements they want. They are only being asked to identify themselves, which should be seen as a form of protection, should certain points be misunderstood or misinterpreted.
I think this is a very important point. During the last election campaign, we saw what poor communications could do to our hon. friends opposite. We would rather not have that experience.
Mr. Speaker, I interpret the speech made by the Leader of the Opposition as provocation. Why should anything be off the record? Why can we not identify ourselves when we have something to say?

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
subsubtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION-INFORMATION GUIDELINES
speechtext: The comment and question period on the speech of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Turner) is now over. We shall now resume debate.

subsubtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION-INFORMATION GUIDELINES
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to speak today about secrecy in government. Not since the last war have Canadians had a government so obsessed with secrecy as they have today. Of course, the reason for government secrecy in the last war was to keep vital information from the enemy, but the reason for government secrecy today is to keep vital information from the Canadian people.
Secrecy and stonewalling have become a habit with the Government of Canada. We will never break the habit until we change the Government. I should like to say that I am
November 27, 1984

plagiarizing the words of the current Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney) when he was the Leader of the Opposition and stated: "The differences between the present administration and a new Conservative government is simply this: the present government believes you only have limited rights to know; Conservatives believe you have every right to know". That was the statement of the Prime Minister last August when he was Leader of the Opposition.
The people of Canada should not accept such secretive behaviour. Secrecy, stealth and stonewalling have become trademarks of the present Government. What do they have to conceal from the people of Canada? What sort of parliamentary government is it when we have a system within which Cabinet can create a corporation by Orders in Council, staff it with patronage appointments at undisclosed salary, and then lock the door to keep out the Auditor General, to keep the watchdog of Parliament at bay? That was the position of the current Prime Minister with respect to the responsibilities of the Auditor General when he was in fact the Leader of the Opposition. However, when he in fact became the Leader of the current Government, he denied the access of the Auditor General to the very information which he had pledged as part of his open government and his open government policy prior to the election.
As my Leader has stated, it becomes an issue of trust, an issue of whether the statements made by the current Prime Minister when he was Leader of the Opposition were in fact pre-election pap or whether he had every intention of developing the kind of open government which he promised when he was in Opposition.
It seems to me that when we look at the policy guidelines, the mumming effect of this Government on public servants across the country since the appointment of his political commissars and since his new move into media management, it is clear the Prime Minister had no intention of introducing the kind of open government which he pledged to Canadians.
I should like to bring to the attention of the House a very simple incident in which I happened to be involved as an invitee of the Edmonton Jaycees. A few weeks ago I agreed to participate in a conference on, of all subjects, women in politics and how we could get more women involved in politics. The Jaycees had invited representatives of all political parties to attend and to discuss a subject which I think the Prime Minister has stated is a policy and a priority of his Government.
Nonetheless, when I arrived at the conference I was advised that political commissar Elizabeth Willcocks in the office of the Minister of State for Multiculturalism (Mr. Murta) was ordered by the Prime Minister's office not to attend this conference for fear that in fact she would say something bad about the involvement of women in politics across the country. The political commissar in question had been invited to this conference as a result of her pursuit of the presidency of the Progressive Conservative Party of Canada. I find it incredible that this Government would attempt to muzzle a political commissar who had past experience and certainly past involve-
Supply
ment with Progressive Conservative policies relating to women. It is just another indication of a government that says one thing when it is in opposition with the full intention of not carrying out its political promises when it is elected.
Let us look at the very first initiative of the Government with respect to the economic statement of the Minister of Finance (Mr. Wilson). It has become clear from questioning in the House that the Minister of Finance had information which would tell Canadians that, as a direct result of his Government's policies, his Government's short-term financial intervention, there would be a loss of jobs. In fact, the Government refused to table that information in the House. It refused to make available to Canadians information which would have clearly shown that the economic statement tabled by the Minister of Finance would in fact reduce jobs. I cannot agree more with the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Turner) when he states that Canadians will not be fooled. It is my understanding that Canadian voters in the Province of Prince Edward Island were not fooled by this Government. I suppose I should congratulate the Finance Minister because he handed the Liberals of Prince Edward Island an election issue on a platter when he introduced an economic statement which wrought tremendous economic difficulties for the Atlantic provinces, in particular the ferry situation with respect to Prince Edward Island. I should congratulate him on his initiative. I should say that the Canadian people will not be fooled by secrecy or by the broken promises of the Government because they are recognizing that the trust factor which became an issue during the election campaign has not subsided.
When I read the statement of the Public Service Alliance of Canada-I think it puts the question very carefully to Canadians-to suggest that there need to be more restrictions placed upon public employees is to suggest that there need to be two classes of citizens in this country. The Alliance agrees that Public Service employees should provide information to the public and the media regarding government programs and policies and that in the past government employees have been needlessly prevented from doing so.
The issue here is a promise made by the current Prime Minister to run an open government and to tell Canadians upon what basis the current Government will make decisions with respect to economic policy. What we have instead is a government run by political commissars, a government run by "check it with Erik", a government where the Prime Minister has clearly violated the promises which he made to Canadians for an open system.
I suggest that if the Government is to begin to go back on the road of broken promises upon which it has already set itself, the first issue it should address is the issue of secrecy in government. Instead of issuing guidelines to muzzle public servants and instead of having Ministers such as the Minister of Transport (Mr. Mazankowski) memo departments on witch-hunts for former Liberal employees, et cetera, the Government should in fact tell Canadians that as of this day forward public servants will certainly have the right to speak

November 27, 1984
Supply
out on issues and to lay out policy options and let them know that the Government is not afraid of letting information out.
If I look at the department responsible for housing, Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation organizations across the land know that CMCH is developing its priority list for housing projects. Yet I was advised earlier this week that in fact the housing priority list cannot be given out to interested groups and organizations because again the Government is attempting by media manipulation to manage the news and to prevent information which is of vital importance to interested parties in the housing industry from in fact being exposed.
I refer also to a simple peace conference which was held recently and an article indicating that the muzzle may affect that peace conference. There is no Hon. Member in the House who would disagree with the initiatives of the peace conference. The Hon. Secretary of State for External Affairs (Mr. Clark), notwithstanding his reticence about the media, would agree that information of the sort which would emerge from this peace conference will be very important. However, it was indicated in a recent newspaper article that organizers of a university seminar on nuclear disarmament said that they had been receiving telephone calls from worried public servants who were reluctant to attend meetings because journalists were also scheduled to attend. I know there are a number of former journalists on the government side of the House. I am sure they would agree that it is appropriate, when trying to give out information to allow policy decisions to be made, that all policy options be explored and that public servants have the authority from their Ministers to give out this kind of information.
This Government through its political commissars, media management and mass manipulation has denied that right, not only to the Canadian people but to Members of Parliament who of necessity have the need from time to time for off-the-record briefings with Ministers' staff and departmental officials.
If this Government is willing to repair its current image in the minds of Canadian voters-and I do not have to remind Government members of the massive mandate for change they were given in the last election-it will not refuse to open the doors of information, allow Canadians access to information and allow Members of Parliament the tools that we need to carry out our function as an effective, critical Official Opposition. If not, it will have broken the first of many promises it made to the Canadian people.
I am sorry that the Prime Minister is not here currently to join in the debate. He stated last August that he believed in open government. He stated that Conservatives were not afraid of letting information out to the Canadian people. He said that a new government would result in a massive new direction, including access to information by the Auditor General. Having said all that, I am sure that he will stand in his place this afternoon and clarify to the Canadian people why his Government has changed course, why he has broken
his promises and why the open government which he pledged last August has become a government of secrecy, a government of manipulation, a government which is not prepared to let the Canadian people in on the economic situation of this country.
I expect the Leader of the Opposition, as he has done so ably in the last few weeks, to continue to press on this issue. It is a matter of liberty and rights, not only for Members of Parliament but for all Canadians. All Canadians have a right to know how many jobs were eliminated as a result of the financial statement. Canadians have a right to know what policy initiatives this Governmment will be studying with regard to universal accessibility.
Is this Government going to do away with the baby bonus, as has been suggested in the economic discursives of the Minister of Finance? Is this Government going to jack up the cost of unemployment insurance benefits and reduce them to the point that unemployment insurance will become the right of welfare recipients only?
Is this Government going to do away with the child tax credit in a move that has been described by some as the most anti-child and anti-young people initiative ever ventured upon by any government in this country? Is this Government going to carry out these initiatives or will it allow the Canadian people to be involved in a full and open discussion on the initiatives introduced in the economic statement tabled by the Minister of Finance?
Canadians want to know the answers to these questions. They want to know whether old age benefits are going to be reduced as a result of this Government's lack of commitment to universal access. Canadians want to know what the future of the child tax credit will be. They want to know whether it is government policy to eliminate summer jobs for young people. Canadians want to know what kind of two-step shuffle this Government was embarked upon when it made promises to the Canadian people last August that it refuses to deliver upon in November.

Mr. Speaker, I just want to add that Canadians have a right to know what kind of policies the Government is considering. Before being elected, the Right Hon. Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney) promised all Canadians they would have open government, government that would give all Canadians access to information. We know what happened. As soon as he was elected, the Prime Minister forgot all his promises and now, we have a Government where secrecy and political commissars are the order of the day. As they say in Parliament, you always have to-

"Check it with Erik". That is the hallmark of this Government: "Check it with Erik". The Canadian people did not elect just one Member of Parliament. They elected Members of Parliament on all sides of the House, all of whom are charged with the responsibility of getting access to information and ensuring that the Canadian people have access to information
November 27, 1984

so that we can make informed policy decisions, and in the case of the Official Opposition offer constructive criticism. That is our role in Parliament.

And I believe the Government made a number of promises in that regard during the election campaign. A lot has been said, Mr. Speaker, about the guidelines put forward by the Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney). I was very interested in the responses we received with respect to these guidelines. You would think, Mr. Speaker, that we have brought forward some sort of new monster, some draconian set of rules which are unprecedented in terms of public policy. Nothing could be further from the truth. I believe what we have now, Mr. Speaker, is a very responsible initiative taken by the Prime Minister.
These are not new guidelines. They are in effect the guidelines which were first initiated by the Right Hon. Member for
Yellowhead (Mr. Clark) when he was Prime Minister. Ultimately, after some public pressure, they were accepted by the Right Hon. Pierre Trudeau, when he was Prime Minister, and his administration. These are the same guidelines, with one exception. I want to address myself to that exception because it has been the subject matter of some comment not only in Question Period but also in statements made by spokespersons for the Liberal Party.
I think we all recognize the basic premise as stated by the Prime Minister and enunciated in the guidelines. The Public Service has not only a right but an obligation to give full and factual information to the people of Canada. This is not the preserve of a few people in the Press Gallery or those few of us who have been privileged to be elected as members of the House of Commons. The people of Canada have a right to information and the preservation of that right is one that we in this Party and the Government regard as the most serious undertaking we have.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Leader of the New Democratic Party (Mr. Broadbent) has this condition: Whenever he hears a statement of fact he twitches and shouts. I want to tell him that if he twitches and shouts much more I may have to ask for an extension of time, because he is interrupting a very important message.
What we are determined to do, Mr. Speaker, is ensure that information is obtainable from the Public Service to everyone in Canada. We want to establish the clear and understandable precedent that people in the Public Service have an obligation to give out this information. Indeed, we feel so strongly about that that we have no compunctions about this being done without any concern on the part of public servants about making their identity known when making information public and on the record. Now, what could be more helpful to the dissemination of information? Public servants know that when they give information out they cannot be subject to any disciplinary action because they are in fact quite free to say: "Yes, 1 am a public servant but I say these are the facts". This does not require any clearance from any Minister.
Unlike the Opposition, we in this Party have the highest regard for the Public Service of this country. We believe them to be intelligent people of great judgment. We do not say that they have to speak off the record. These people are enormously talented, they are working in the interests of Canada, and we have no compunctions about saying that if you are a member of the Public Service it is quite all right that you speak for attribution. You have responsibilities in your department and there is nothing wrong with that.
I ask you, Mr. Speaker, what do we want to have in this country? Do we want a situation where every story that is written refers to sources from certain departments who refuse
November 27, 1984

to be identified and are quoted as saying this or that because under previous guidelines there was great confusion as to whether or not they had the right to speak to the press or to anyone else? Are we going to continue this kind of regime or are we going to offer an up-front, straightforward set of guidelines that everyone understands? We say that they have an obligation to deal with certain areas concerning public policy. They are entitled to give the facts and do not have to worry about whispering it over the phone or whether it is attributed to them or not.
I do not have a suspicious mind, Mr. Speaker. Unlike some members of the Opposition who see everything in very grey areas, we believe the members of the Public Service of this country are worthy of the trust we have demonstrated in them through these guidelines. 1 simply say that we intend to make sure the system works efficiently, not because of any interest we have in putting ourselves in the best possible light, but because we think the public, and particularly the media, must have full access to government information. We want the Public Service to have a very clear understanding of their role in communications. We do not want them to feel they are somehow going to be our advocates on a political position we have taken. We want them to speak out and give the facts, notwithstanding that we have taken a political position. We want to ensure that deputy ministers and senior public servants realize that this Government takes seriously its communications with the public. We want them to understand the basic premise that we must be prepared to deliver information to the public. We want to ensure that each department has people to whom there can be access, either by the media or the average citizen. We want to make sure they get answers on specific issues and do not get that run-around which everyone who has tried to get information from government knows exists within our system. We want to make sure there is a clear understanding of the responsibility of the Public Service to give out the maximum amount of information.
We have not tampered with any policy on communication first enunciated by the Clark Government and subsequently by the Trudeau Government. We want to ensure that there is a clear understanding of what we are doing in the interests of freedom of information and freedom of access to the Public Service. We view this most strongly.
We have taken some initiatives which I think even the Opposition will applaud. What we are going to do in two or three areas will be a clear indication that we are not going to try to manipulate the news or use taxpayers' funds for the purpose of putting across our point of view and political philosophy, as the last government did during the Constitution debate and the energy debate. Hundreds of millions of dollars of taxpayers' money were used for crass political purposes. We are going to stop that regime and do it on a sensible and fair basis. We are going to do it through a substantial reduction in the advertising bill of this Government with respect to what transpired in the past.
We are going to take some other initiatives, as we already have by doing away with the propaganda arm of the previous
Supply
government; the Canadian Unity Information Office has been terminated. No longer will we have a situation where a government has had-and I say this for the benefit of Liberals who do not understand the difference between the proper meaning of "management" and the word "manipulation"-an arm whose sole function was to manipulate the news, manipulate opinion poll sampling, and manipulate everything that went on in government for the political well-being of the Liberal Party.
I can assure you, Mr. Speaker, that the people of Canada understand fairness and the idea that there is a message which has to be delivered concerning government services. There are many services we deliver. But we are going to move away from the crass political way in which the previous government attempted to politicize the Public Service of this country. From now on the tradition of an independent Public Service is one which we are going to defend and bring to people across Canada, and it will be seen to be a fair policy and a fair initiative on our part.
I see you are indicating that I am near the end of my time, Mr. Speaker, so I simply want to say in conclusion that we in our Party have a history of consultation. We had the Revenue Canada task force, and task force on VIA Rail. We have gone out to see the people. We are not embarrassed or ashamed to take the people of Canada into our confidence. That has been demonstrated by us as a historical tradition, and it is a policy we will continue within this Government.
One has to ask the question: Why has the Liberal Party brought this issue before the House? Where do they stand on the important issues with respect to the economy? What policies do they have to bring forward with respect to unemployment? What is their attitude concerning economic thrust? Who speaks for the Liberal Party? What does that Party stand for on the issues the people of Canada want to hear about? I simply say that we have the opportunity to deal with important issues. I make the commitment to you, Mr. Speaker, on behalf of my Party that we are a Party of openness and we will continue to operate in the best interests of accessibility. We have the most consultative government in the history of our country. We intend to carry on with our mandate by consulting with the Canadian people and we will see the results of the policies we are initiating after full consultation in a spirit of openness.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate that question because I think it is a fair question. The statement by our very revered colleague, Mr. Baker, who is no longer with us, is an indication of a serious proposal which was put forward. Legislative initiatives will be taken under consideration in our
deliberations in Cabinet. I am concerned about the rights of all Members of Parliament to participate in this process. We now have a review which takes place within three years of the operation of that Act. This was brought about primarily by the initiative of Mr. Baker. The Leader of the Opposition said today that the jury is out with respect to that matter. I have a problem in terms of acting unilaterally because I respect the ability of Members of Parliament to come to grips with the matter and work on consensus to attain the best possible solution.

The people of Canada had some reason to have positive expectations about a new government moving in a systematic and democratic way to provide more access to information. The present Prime Minister made statements and indeed the former Conservative Prime Minister had taken action when he was Prime Minister that gave us reason to be plausibly optimistic.
What happened after September 4? First, there was the reaction of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr. Nielsen) whose approach to what the Cabinet and the new Government was doing clearly did amount to an attempt to manipulate the news. What we say from the former Prime Minister, the current Secretary of State for External Affairs, can only politely be described as a slight case of paranoia with regard to the media. A most extraordinary set of statements came out of the office of the Secretary of State for External Affairs about some powerful elite in the country, which is actually rather a scruffy group, given the three names that were used. They would be the last people whom I would describe as an elite. However, personalities aside, for a new government that preaches openness and concern for democratic rights, the response of the Deputy Prime Minister and the Secretary of State for External Affairs was totally reprehensible. In a matter of days they began to reverse what the Conservatives had promised during the summer campaign. The Conservatives no more believe in freedom of information than they believe in a number of other promises that they made during the election campaign.
Let me deal specifically with the substance of the issue at stake here, as I see it. Within the Cabinet system of government what limitations, if any, ought to be imposed on the public who, in an ultimate democratic sense, have a much deeper and profound right even than Members of Parliament to have access to information? I noticed that the Government House Leader did not spell this out in his speech. Certainly the Right Hon. Leader of the Opposition did not lower himself to suggest a specific criterion that the Liberals would believe acceptable.
I want to suggest a criterion that is consistent with the principles of democratic government, particularly a parliamentary democracy, and ought to be applied by the Government of Canada. I would like to hear some Government members respond to the view of my Party.
In terms of documentation prepared by public servants, whether of a factual or analytic nature, concerning present policy, or factual and analytic nature in terms of an assessment of future impact of present policies, if such studies do not contain material that would impinge negatively on the security of the state, if they do not contain material that would be clearly libellous, if they do not contain material that is pertinent to on-going negotiations of an intergovernmental nature, if, in short, they do not cover one of these three bases, all such factual analytic material ought to be made available to the people of Canada.

I want to take a minute, Mr. Speaker, to explain clearly why I think the Government of Canada is not practising what it is preaching. The Prime Minister gave it all away yesterday in Question Period. I and my colleague, the Hon. Member for Burnaby (Mr. Robinson), were asking questions about the new guidelines. At one point in the Question Period concerning these guidelines I asked the Prime Minister if it were his interpretation that if members of the public, the media, and Members of Parliament requested factual, analytic information with reference to the future, that it was part of the task or the obligation of a public servant to provide information consistent, I believe, with the second guideline that, factual matters of public policy ought to be made available by a public servant. The answer from the Prime Minister, when asked in that form, came in a lowering of the voice. In a sincere tone he said: "Of course. Yes, it should be provided". But when I got more specific and asked if that therefore included studies that might have been done about the impact of multi-million dollar cut-backs in employment programs, multi-million cut-backs in the CBC's operations, multi-million dollar cut-backs in a whole variety of programs, he gave what I can only describe as an incredible answer. He said: "No, not at all". He said that information should not be given. He went on to suggest that if it were, this "would effectively paralyse the Public Service". He described as an impropriety the revelation of such factual studies, such analytic material. He said impropriety would be the way he would describe it in the context of parliamentary democracy; that somehow it would be wrong for a public servant working for the Government of Canada to provide such information.
My response to the Prime Minister's answers yesterday, and I repeat here today, is that he was talking complete and utter nonsense when he said that would be inconsistent with the requirements of parliamentary democracy. What he did and what has been systematically done by this Government in the last week is to equate any kind of factual documentation or analytic study as an item of concern with the right of a civil servant to make private advice and recommendation to his Minister. I see the Government House Leader says that is right.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I listened very carefully to the comments of the Leader of the New Democratic Party. In fairness to him, I think he raised a question which is the subject of legitimate debate. I am very interested in the fact that he wants to pursue the question of what kind of information should be regarded as having Cabinet confidentiality.
I preface my remarks by reminding him that had it not been for the Progressive Conservative Party of Canada, the Party which started the freedom of information legislation and pursued it with vigour, we would not have access to freedom of information legislation. It was our Party which gave leadership in that role. Our legislation was the basis upon which the Liberal government was finally forced to move during the course of the last Parliament.
On the basis of his analysis, is the Leader of the NDP suggesting that advice given to the Government, a Minister or Cabinet should be dissected by someone and that those parts of the information, such as certain charts or statistics used in the course of that advice with approbation and approval to Cabinet or to a Minister, should be hived off and made public? Or does he not believe that in the course of giving advice-and he will understand that Ministers obtain advice which is backed up by a variety of statistics and information-information should be kept in its proper context and that the Minister should be allowed to receive the advice of public servants and not be concerned about its being the subject of partisan and acrimonious debate on the floor of the House of Commons or in the press across the country because it was taken out of context? In the context of advice to a Minister, does he not agree that statistics form part of the advice, or does he want to
hang public servants out to dry so that anything they say can be hived off and the Deputy Minister to the Minister of Finance, or to the Minister of the Environment (Mrs. Blais-Grenier) or whomever, will not have any opportunity to put it back into the context within which it was given to the Minister? Is that what he is proposing, or does he have some other way in which he would propose providing this factual, so-called analytical material?
I am simply saying to the Leader of the New Democratic Party that it is very easy and very facile for him to make these observations and suggestions, but when we have statistics and information forming part of the advice being given to Ministers, how does he propose to deal with it?

Of course, from time to time in such documentation or such argumentation some statistical reference would be made.

However, if I agree with the Minister on that point, he must surely understand that, in addition to the argument, advice or proposal which might be offered, there are other supporting documents or supporting analytical information, for example, the assessment of cut-back proposals running through the economic model of the Department of Finance. PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND-LIBERAL PARTY'S WIN IN BYELECTION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, yesterday the people of the provincial riding of Fourth Kings on Prince Edward Island registered their scores on the performance of the federal and provincial Parties on P.E.I. The final score: NDP, 161; the Conservatives, 1,061; the Liberals, 1,428.
Islanders have said no to higher energy costs, no to higher gasoline prices, no to higher ferry rates, no to increases in national park fees, no to cuts in agricultural programs, no to increases in berthage fees for fishermen, no to reductions in housing programs and, most important, no to the provincial Conservatives who have said that the Mulroney Government understands Prince Edward Island's problems and needs. Islanders have said: "Where are the jobs, jobs, jobs?'' The federal Government has given each and every Islander a job- a snow job. Perhaps now Premier Lee will see that being a yes man to Mulroney's Government is not enough. Perhaps now the federal and provincial Tories will sit up and listen.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to comment on the new redistribution of electoral boundaries.
Basically, my comments will concern three points.
First, costs. We are now in the midst of a period of budgetary restraint, and adding new electoral districts will bring about an increase in direct and indirect costs which would be difficult to justify, considering the state of the deficit.
Second, regional boundaries. New electoral boundaries are always a problem because they may cut across natural regional boundaries. The sense of community remains a very strong concept, and any changes will have a social and economic impact on our constituents, in addition to the fact of having to adjust to a new administrative and political milieu which is complex enough as it is.
Third, the solutions proposed. These almost always require shifting populations from one constituency to another. However, since there is an increasing movement towards the urban centres, why not consider a more practical and permanent solution based both on the number of people and the geoeconomic milieu?
Mr. Speaker, we hope that these items will be taken into account when the Election Act is discussed.

Mr. Speaker, over the past 50 years Canadians in all parts of Canada have benefited from telephone systems which are almost universal, systems that provide them with good, efficient telephone service at a moderate price.
At the present time the CRTC is considering an application from CNCP Telecommunications to enter the long distance telephone business, which would change the whole system of telephone usage in Canada. That application is being opposed by a variety of groups. It has been opposed by the three prairie Governments. I quote from a letter from the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of the Conservative Government of Saskatchewan:
It is the Saskatchewan Government's position that CNCP's entry into long distance service would benefit only a few select customers in Ontario, Quebec and British Columbia.
If the CRTC were to approve that application, it would change our whole system. The application raises a policy question which should be dealt with at the federal-provincial level. We urgently call on the Minister of Communications (Mr. Masse) to convene a federal-provincial conference on telecommunication policy and to instruct the CRTC to hold its decision until a national policy is established by the elected representatives of the people.

Mr. Speaker, the purpose of my statement is to draw the attention of Hon. Members to the urgent problem facing the livestock and poultry industry in the Maritime provinces.
Livestock and poultry production in the Maritimes was worth $375 million in 1983. That industry has a labour force in excess of 6,500 people and the economic activities related to the industry inject $1 billion into our economy every year. However, the survival and future growth of the industry rest on the possibility of equalizing feed grain prices between the Maritime provinces and the rest of Canada.
[English)
In 1966 the Livestock Feed Assistance Act was passed. One of its stated objectives was "the fair equalization of feed grain prices in eastern Canada''. In 1984 this assistance covered only 20 per cent of the transportation costs, creating a $30 a tonne difference in costs between the Maritimes and central Canada.
[ Translation]
Mr. Speaker, the solution would be that the Maritime provinces become self-sufficient in the production of feed grain. Self-sufficiency would make for a secure and stable industry and contribute to better agricultural land use. The Maritime provinces have enough land to achieve self-sufficiency within 15 years, but immediate action must be taken.

In summary, we have a feed cost disparity problem which is creating an emergency situation for our pork industry and a heavy burden on other livestock sectors. Left unattended, we stand to lose 4,000 to 5,000 jobs. Properly addressed, we could add 4,000 to 5,000 new jobs.

RETIREMENT OF GUY LAFLEUR, HOCKEY PLAYER EXTRAORDINAIRE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in most of the world "flower power" may have come and gone with the 1960s, but in Montreal it started in 1971 and lasted until yesterday when Guy Lafleur finally said:

"Enough is enough".
This is the end of a great era. Yesterday, after playing 14 years in the National Hockey League, Guy Lafleur announced that he was hanging up his skates permanently. With a career total of 518 goals, he was the second best goal scorer in the history of the Montreal Canadiens, just behind Maurice Richard. He is one of a very select group of nine NHL players with a career total of more than 500 goals. Between 1974 and 1979, he had six consecutive 50-goal seasons.
During 14 years, Guy Lafleur was truly a great star, an idol of the 1970s. He is the last in a line of superstars which included Jean Beliveau and Maurice Richard.
I am sure the House and all Canadians wish him the best of luck in his future endeavours-

-and thanks for the memories.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise today to speak on the motion before this House.
I think it useful that I remind Hon. Members of what the motion says in light of the extraordinary Question Period we have just witnessed. The motion reads:
That, in the opinion of this House, the guidelines issued by the Prime Minister, on November 23, 1984, with regard to the provision of information to the public, are inadequate and retrogressive and confirm the Government's mistrust of and cynicism toward Canadians.
I want to underline two words from the motion, "mistrust of' and "cynicims" toward Canadians.
We have just had the spectacle of the Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney) desperately reaching way back to his St. F.X. debating days, to his Laval debating days when he was for two years in a row, we are told in his official biography, the student club debating champion, to try and find some way to gloss over what was very apparent in this House-an attempt by his Minister of Finance (Mr. Wilson) to be, on the one hand, presenting as government policy and the official position of the Government facts a, b, and c, while in his back pocket the real position of the Government of Canada, the real facts with respect to the transfer of payments as they affect the Province of Manitoba, were disguised. They were available to him but deliberately withheld from the representatives of the people of Manitoba and indeed Manitobans themselves.
My real concern, having witnessed that spectacle of the Prime Minister flippantly defending that action by his Minister, is that somehow the Prime Minister, who comes here every day with 210 cheerleaders and 210 who clap their hands, misunderstands the mood of the country. He misunderstands the very serious state at which his Government after only a few

November 27, 1984
Supply
months in office has arrived. Each day, no matter what the issue or how flippant and cynical the Prime Minister's answer, he hears 210 pairs of clapping hands in this House. He has taken to listening to the applause. He goes out of this House believing that he has won the day because he has heard the most applause, believing that the fundamental issue of a government's relationship to the people, and the fundamental issue of openness and honesty between jurisdictions, has gone by the wayside.
I have a piece of advice for the Prime Minister, Mr. Speaker. If he wants to understand how deeply the concern is by Canadians today about the approach of this Government and its dealings with the public, with Members of this House and with provincial governments, he should bring a pair of earplugs into this House and stick them in his ears so that he can weigh questions and the flippant answers he has provided more objectively. For days I have been asking the Government, which claims that it wants to consult, to be open and honest, to clarify what has happened to a report known as the environmental assessment impact study by Mobil, the operator of the Hibernia development. Last Wednesday and again yesterday and today, the Prime Minister told us in the House that his Government had the report. In the November 23, 1984 edition of The Globe and Mail, an article concerning the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources (Miss Carney) headlined "Carney awaits Hibernia decision" read in part as follows:
I delayed Mobil's acceptance . . . pending clarification of how the resource should be developed-
She has not accepted the report. The Premier of Newfoundland has risen in the Newfoundland House of Assembly almost daily for the last two weeks to deny that he has seen the report. The Prime Minister fell into a trap, the trap of truth. He answered a question truthfully. He said: "We have the documentation, we have the information", but he forgot to find out what his Minister of Energy was saying in Newfoundland to a reporter from The Globe and Mail. I wonder how he will square that one when the Minister of Energy returns.
What is in that report? What does that report address? How will Hibernia be developed? That is a very complex question with dramatic economic impact for Newfoundland, be it floating concrete platforms or semi-submersible rigs. It is the difference between 1,500 and 50,000 jobs. The answer is contained in the report which has been mugged and gagged by order of both governments for six months. How fast will production take place? What will be the rate of development? That is addressed in the report. How will the federal-provincial management agency function? Who is the great Solomon who will be the neutral chairman proposed by both agencies? That question and how that should be undertaken and accomplished is addressed in the report.
How will the so-called 25 per cent back-in provided to Petro-Canada, a portion of which is to be shared with the provincial government, be handled when the federal Government committed itself to getting rid of the 25 per cent
back-in? Indeed, the Government of Newfoundland-and the Government of Nova Scotia already has an agreement-has as part of the agreement a share of the 25 per cent back-in provision.
These are not esoteric questions. These are questions which will impact directly on how Newfoundland can expect to share in the benefits of a resource adjacent to its shores. We have seen nothing but a conspiracy of silence from this Government.
Earlier this morning the Government House Leader stood and told the House that this was the most open government in the land, that this Government in all matters affecting Canadians, regardless of where they live, would consult them, ask for their opinions and ensure that they understood the impact of government policy. He even assured us that he would try to understand the impact of government policy.
In the economic statement of November 16, 1984, presented by the Minister of Finance, we see either cancellations or dramatic cuts in Atlantic Canada alone affecting 24 programs. They will impact negatively upon the people who live in the poorest provinces of Canada. They involve 24 programs and there has been no consultation. A Liberal member of the House of Assembly in Prince Edward Island was elected yesterday. The member who vacated that seat to run federally sits across from me now. The fine gentleman that he is, he knows why they lost that seat. It was because without any consultation in an island province a rate increase was applied to ferry transport. It is not a scenic route by the sea or a pleasant way to spend a day; it is a mode of transportation to move goods and services. Ferry transport was attacked by the Government and a rate increase of 15 per cent was applied with no consultation with the people of P.E.I. There was no discussion. There was no regard to the reality that 99 per cent of the goods consumed by the people of P.E.I. is moved by ferry traffic. It is not flown in. It is not trucked in. It is not driven in. It is not flung in. It is moved across the water. The same is true for Newfoundland. Therefore the people of Prince Edward Island returned a Liberal member to the Hon. Member's vacated seat because they were not consulted. They did it because they did not hear the voice of Conservative members from P.E.I. in this Chamber demanding redress for the arbitrary and unilateral action of the federal Government.
Where was the consultation when RRAP was scrapped? Where was the consultation when COSP was scrapped? Where was the consultation when CHIP was scrapped? Where was the consultation when the Prime Minister of Canada broke his solemn word in cancelling the federal forestry centre for Corner Brook, Newfoundland?
I should like to relate a little history. For two years I fought inside and outside the House, publicly and privately, with Ministers, including members of my own Party, to have the forestry centre moved from St. John's, Newfoundland to Corner Brook. It was a S16 million project approved by Cabinet. The funding was provided by Treasury Board under the adminsitration of the former Prime Minister, the Right Hon. Pierre Elliott Trudeau. During the election campaign it became an issue. I suggested to my constituents that this
November 27, 1984

Government, taking its orders from the hon. joker from St. John's West, would cancel that centre if it were elected. The local candidate in my riding was so aggrieved that he announced that unless the matter was clarified he would cease to be a candidate. He sent a telegram to the Prime Minister saying: "Will you confirm that if our Party is elected this forestry centre will proceed?" The Prime Minister sent a telegram to the candidate in question. He also sent one to the mayor of Corner Brook, George Hutchings, in which he said:
The allegations by the Liberal MP for your area to the effect that I or my party is opposed to the proposed federal forestry centre being located in Corner Brook are completely without substance. I assure you as I have assured our PC candidate, Mike Monaghan, that I fully support the establishment of the federal forestry centre in Corner Brook.
Those were the Prime Minister's own words over his signature. What did the Minister of Finance announce on that fateful Thursday when he brought down his financial statement? One of the cut-backs he announced or one of the programs cancelled was the federal forestry centre move from St. John's to Corner Brook, Newfoundland.
I do not know what kind of definition the Prime Minister of Canada applies to truth. The people I represent face an unemployment rate of 27 per cent, according to the latest statistics of the Minister of Employment and Immigration (Miss MacDonald). These people have seen 750 industrial jobs lost in a pulp and paper mill a year ago April. They have just been advised that another 160 jobs will be lost in the next six months. They have seen a very serious decline in the fishing industry. They live in a geographic area of 550 miles wherein 60 per cent of them live in communities with populations under 500.
The people I represent believe that a man's word is worth something. It is not having the Prime Minister on paper that was important. That did not really matter. It was a piece of correspondence to a mayor. What was important was that they had his word. All 90,000 souls, most of whom live in small isolated communities, saw him on CBC, the only television network they receive. They heard him on CFCB and on CBC radio. They heard his words-"I am not opposed to this move which will create jobs for your area. If my Party is elected, the move will go ahead as budgeted for under Treasury Board". They believed him because they are good, decent and believing people. They think that any man who aspires to be Prime Minister of Canada would keep his word when he gives it. That is the right, proper and decent thing to do. They do not expect to see a man stand in his place and treat flippantly and as a joke, to the applause of 211 pairs of senseless clapping hands, that kind of important question.
I would ask the Prime Minister, were he here, whether he thinks that is a good joke, or is the Prime Minister a liar? That is what I would ask him. The people in the area I represent take as an act of faith a man's word. They do not mince words. That same man has played them for a fool. It is a simple one word description. They ask him if he is a liar. If he were here, I would be interested in seeing how he would answer.

I did not expect and no member of this House expected, whether it be NDP or Liberal, that a few months after the election we would be sitting here engaged in this kind of debate about the fundamental credibility of the administration elected on September 4. I thought we were going to proceed with caution but not with paranoia. I thought we were going to see a government be decisive, but not unduly quick, not to the point of riding rough-shod over the rights of journalists, Members of Parliament and the public of this country.
I thought there would be what has been traditionally described as the period of grace before any heated words were exchanged in this Commons. Much to my surprise and I am sure to the surprise of the people of Canada-and we knew they could not meet the promises of the summer of 1984-not only do they refuse to keep their promises, but they have put under attack the fundamental social programs that are the underpinnings of the least advantaged areas of this country- Atlantic Canada, the North and parts of the West. I give the Prime Minister warning to draw upon all his oratorical skills and great debating experience because I will have the opportunity in a few days to ask him in this House if he has lied. speechtext:
The House Leader suggests it does not enhance my reputation. However, as I said earlier, the people who sent me here took as an article of faith the word of the Prime Minister of Canada. It is quite simple. It is not complicated. They did not ask for it in blood. They did not even ask for it in writing, although they got it in writing. They will equally want a straightforward and simple definition of what has gone wrong.
How could such a promise made by a Prime Minister be contained in the list of programs to be cut in a budget provided to this House under the direction and with the approval of the Prime Minister by the Minister of Finance? That is the question that is addressed in this motion today. The cynicism is not the fact that this Government has broken promises. It is the ease with which it is prepared to break promises that is bothersome. It is not the fact that it is prepared to be secret, not the fact that it wants to manipulate and manage the news which bothers us so much; it is the flippant way in which they defend it, with big grins on their faces, as the crowd applauds. The best advice I can give this Prime Minister and his Cabinet is to get some ear plugs and wear them. They might be able to get a much more objective view of this country. I warn them that the eyes of the people of Canada are on you in those first few months. They best not try their patience much further.
